document.title: Mathematics Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

DBEBB601364B4B5394699DDB4D66620A.description:
Solve contextual problems that involve identifying, describing, and extending increasing and
decreasing patterns using single-operation input and output rules.

04AD8A659785452CBD082517C0F33FD4.description:
Given a rule, create increasing and decreasing patterns using numbers and input/output tables
(including function machines).

15E952A95908411883E88A53905F7D73.description:
Analyze an increasing or decreasing single-operation numerical pattern found in lists,
input/output tables, or function machines and generalize the change to identify the rule,
extend the pattern, or identify missing terms.

62DA984F053D438CBE0AFEDA7364A3B9.description:
Identify, describe, extend, and create increasing and decreasing patterns using various
representations (e.g., objects, pictures, numbers, number lines, input/output tables, and
function machines).

3C28FF977CCE45F095BC373BBB7F396F.description:
The student will identify, describe, extend, and create increasing and decreasing
patterns (limited to addition, subtraction, and multiplication of whole numbers),
including those in context, using various representations.

5BF41D16F61D4802A75ED0BF89C4EF88.description: Create a model or contextual problem to represent a given probability.

3A0AB99D7DBF4820A1329175D5B79CC1.description:
Determine the likelihood of an event occurring and relate it to its whole number or fractional
representation (e.g., impossible or zero; equally likely; certain or one).

9C1638C4BB884A95BA658AC38EEE7153.description:
Write the probability of a given simple event as a fraction between 0 and 1, where there are no
more than 24 possible outcomes.

4ADD03ECEBEA409BB40C8AE984C6D616.description:
Model and determine all possible outcomes of a given simple event where there are no more
than 24 possible outcomes, using a variety of manipulatives (e.g., coins, two-sided counters,
number cubes, spinners).

3F658D411ADA4504BD5982F077CB7BA9.description:
Describe probability as the degree of likelihood of an outcome occurring using terms such as
impossible, unlikely, equally likely, likely, and certain.

24699E573649414C835574D145F6937C.description: The student will model and determine the probability of an outcome of a simple event.

D59C02557417490696633B7CC035D88A.description:
solve single-step and multistep addition and subtraction problems using data from line
graphs.

5854C8D3DC61472F9A30FBDFD0587DC5.description:
draw conclusions about the data and make predictions based on the data to answer
questions; and

52461C704BFE4B44BAFD1AEE5A07E83B.description: make inferences about data represented in line graphs;

D6163023E82B4FD3837A1185054636A7.description:
identify parts of the data that have special characteristics and explain the meaning of the
greatest, the least, or the same (e.g., the highest temperature shows the warmest day);

33E61B8BB02B4A4282C7F2CDCCC31E0C.description:
describe the characteristics of the data represented in a line graph and the data as a whole
(e.g., the time period when the temperature increased the most);

1A81B4268C614865BAF356EC43E7E07D.description: Analyze data represented in line graphs and communicate results orally and in writing:

17F0F383BE8041639CDBE9882196CD2B.description:
Organize and represent a data set using line graphs with a title and labeled axes with whole
number increments, with and without the use of technology tools.

225218FD54CA4862AF1797934C52AC9A.description:
Determine the data needed to answer a formulated question and collect or acquire existing
data (limited to 10 or fewer data points) using various methods (e.g., observations,
measurements, experiments).

10D377E1B5AD499C897F30228070CFDA.description: Formulate questions that require the collection or acquisition of data.

CA7862A34B20462188BAC0186899939A.description:
Compare and contrast plane and solid figures (limited to circles, squares, triangles, rectangles,
spheres, cubes, square pyramids, and rectangular prisms) according to their characteristics
(number of sides, angles, vertices, edges, and the number and shape of faces).

829E10385F094E46B031704E04610D38.description:
Identify and describe solid figures (cube, rectangular prism, square pyramid, and sphere)
according to their characteristics (number of angles, vertices, edges, and by the number and
shape of faces).

6C3796C1B5DE4921BF9424DDB8E9033C.description:
Identify concrete models and pictorial representations of solid figures (cube, rectangular
prism, square pyramid, sphere, cone, and cylinder).

7E0391F9859D47CBACC70D58893D6B62.description:
The student will identify, describe, compare, and contrast plane and solid figures
according to their characteristics (number of angles, vertices, edges, and the number
and shape of faces), with and without models.

3CAC301206A84535AA559D1D22CA44D6.description: Use symbolic notation to name line segments and angles in quadrilaterals.

A7C65740F04640F9BF08EFECBF465D90.description:
Denote properties of quadrilaterals and identify parallel sides, congruent sides, and right
angles by using geometric markings.

D60919FFA41F41D1A898AAE2AB4D1BDA.description:
Compare, contrast, and classify quadrilaterals (parallelograms, rectangles, squares, rhombi,
and/or trapezoids) based on the following properties and attributes:

80312BEC23DA4EFCA0B6FF1B395589FB.description:
Identify and describe parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, and congruent sides in
quadrilaterals.

76B1B7CC3B30413EAA579E02A3B4F8F9.description: Identify and describe points, line segments, angles, and vertices in quadrilaterals.

7C5D161E63854310AF47072E870C3504.description:
Develop definitions for parallelograms, rectangles, squares, rhombi, and trapezoids through
the exploration of properties and attributes.

7032EE84A3E94148B41DE49535BDB417.description:
The student will classify and describe quadrilaterals (parallelograms, rectangles,
squares, rhombi, and/or trapezoids) using specific properties and attributes.

66E251CE5A9A4CA389DCAB902D4E6CC8.description:
Use symbolic notation to name points, lines, line segments, rays, angles, and to describe
parallel and perpendicular lines.

0FA1B8F07D894129AE964EA87884C11D.description:
Identify parallel, perpendicular, and intersecting lines and line segments in plane and solid
figures, including those in context.

C4380348DA814E75AFD8B6C570E13BF4.description:
Draw representations of points, line segments, rays, angles, and lines, using a ruler or
straightedge.

78D4CE4494B34B72AE51D8C4A1CD63C2.description: Describe endpoints and vertices in relation to lines, line segments, rays, and angles.

C388880FE0AE49DB97A9B351464A5BD6.description:
Identify and describe points, lines, line segments, rays, and angles, including endpoints and
vertices.

EEF18A26E4BD4BF38E585EAF9B6334A4.description:
The student will identify, describe, and draw points, rays, line segments, angles, and
lines, including intersecting, parallel, and perpendicular lines.

DBBA246650F345FF98AB277E13C4769D.description: Solve contextual problems involving area and perimeter of rectangles and squares.

DDF31529B33E40DC870C462CCE79988F.description:
Identify and represent rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same
area and different perimeters.

A8B725E9FFFE43FC8BA1CE5B852CBD5F.description:
Use concrete materials and pictorial models to explore the relationship between area and
perimeter of rectangles.

882AB1A1956643DA9DCD7B127B4566C9.description:
Determine the area and perimeter of a square when given the measure of one side (in whole
number units), with and without models.

A18C1A3E325C440BBF532BFD99BC47F6.description:
Determine the area and perimeter of a rectangle when given the measure of two adjacent sides
(in whole number units), with and without models.

86F216DF98D94246B1718215FECA87CE.description:
Use concrete materials and pictorial models to develop a formula for the area and perimeter of
a rectangle (including a square).

33F0DA2CAABE488CB08920943E02096D.description:
The student will use multiple representations to develop and use formulas to solve
problems, including those in context, involving area and perimeter limited to
rectangles and squares (in both U.S. Customary and metric units).

2D20232C8F9545FA9EB1CAC76F6943BD.description:
the ending time and the amount of elapsed time in hours and minutes, determine the
starting time.

C8D3059F547742408BD859C8A7FEF253.description:
the starting time and amount of elapsed time in hours and minutes, determine the ending
time; or

EFFE7F7A2AA0420B8ACF04831E4A94F9.description:
the starting time and the ending time, determine the amount of time that has elapsed in
hours and minutes;

99057D9B857D48F8984EA84343774BAA.description:
Solve single-step and multistep contextual problems involving elapsed time in hours and
minutes, within a 12-hour period (within a.m., within p.m., and across a.m. and p.m.) when
given:

30B587BAAF624A518D21A757D9647CD0.description:
The student will solve single-step and multistep contextual problems involving elapsed
time (limited to hours and minutes within a 12-hour period).

C6EFAC4AB8AB431BBD62418202F01F16.description: liquid volume (cups, pints, quarts, and gallons).

5228777AA8F849E8BA7D245739DE0DBC.description: length (inches and feet, feet and yards, inches and yards);

889A1926EFEA46F9A12DC758977BDBE5.description:
Given the equivalent measure of one unit, solve problems, including those in context, by
determining the equivalent measures within the U.S. Customary system for:

3D7BEE1742DA44AA9B9A947E21246EC6.description: Compare estimates of length, weight/mass, or liquid volume with the actual measurements.

E1F313285C3D45CD944C3F2A211982A9.description:
liquid volume to the nearest U.S. Customary unit (cup, pint, quart, gallon) and nearest
metric unit (milliliter, liter).

2CE98E8E0D1F47B4B8476B58805C60F1.description:
weight/mass of an object to the nearest U.S. Customary unit (ounce, pound) and nearest
metric unit (gram, kilogram); and

7DB747D6F3E1463CB7CD1C0A8086F316.description:
length of an object to the nearest U.S. Customary unit (1
2
inch, 1
4
inch, 1
8
inch, foot, yard)
and nearest metric unit (millimeter, centimeter, or meter);

65D8B34C8F5B44BCB28AD080D799E287.description:
liquid volume in both U.S. Customary (cup, pint, quart, gallon) and metric units
(milliliter, liter).

5762F0F7D06F4D6CBAE2292D076B6AA6.description:
weight/mass in both U.S. Customary (ounce, pound) and metric units (gram, kilogram);
and

84A51960914D4279A2465780697AB3C9.description:
length in both U.S. Customary (inch, foot, yard, mile) and metric units (millimeter,
centimeter, meter);

98C8C8AA2B1C44CBA2BD6B0A9DBC6625.description: Determine an appropriate unit of measure to use when measuring:

E6C26F276AD34B46B4FE74C9749D73C2.description:
The student will reason mathematically to solve problems, including those in context,
that involve length, weight/mass, and liquid volume using U.S. Customary and metric
units.

63C24D970BFD4D5098876A33AEA77527.description:
Estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and multistep contextual
problems using addition and subtraction of decimals through the thousandths.

1AA48F16DBA645A0836C0A8DFAD5CBC6.description: addends, subtrahends, and minuends are limited to four digits.

8E5D792B30AB41A98E7A9318B035DD63.description: decimals do not exceed the thousandths; and

1FF7C6323E2C4FA7B017307B15E401B3.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., rounding to the nearest whole number, using compatible numbers) and
algorithms, including the standard algorithm, to estimate and determine the sum or difference
of two decimals through the thousandths, with and without models, in which:*

CBE397D3CA7F47E6BABE3FEB7E4AB42F.description:
The student will estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and
multistep problems, including those in context, using addition and subtraction of
decimals through the thousandths, with and without models.

98DC4F787C484EB7840DC157FECC7A57.description:
Apply the inverse property of multiplication in models (e.g., use a visual fraction model to
represent 4
4
or 1 as the product of 4 × 1
4
).

00923C5773C346F6B7D8C65B46E8BF23.description:
Solve single-step contextual problems involving multiplication of a whole number, limited to
12 or less, and a unit fraction (e.g., 6 × 1
3
,
1
5
× 8, 2 ×
1
10
), with models.*

BB29966181F84DEA8F4AF376C08044D1.description:
Estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step contextual problems using
addition and subtraction with fractions (proper or improper) and/or mixed numbers, having
like denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, and 12, and simplify the resulting fraction.
Addition and subtraction with fractions may include regrouping.

E49CE527EAFD48FFAC0DDD9702931E92.description:
Estimate and determine the sum or difference of two fractions (proper or improper) and/or
mixed numbers, having like denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, and 12 (e.g., 3
8
+ 3
8
, 21
5
+ 4
5
,
7
4
-
5
4
) and simplify the resulting fraction. Addition and subtraction with fractions may
include regrouping.*

6A77351D6EF940CE8DBD034AE1C365DF.description:
The student will estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step problems,
including those in context, using addition and subtraction of fractions (proper,
improper, and mixed numbers with like denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, and 12),
with and without models; and solve single-step contextual problems involving
multiplication of a whole number (12 or less) and a unit fraction, with models.

D0150E3C75DF4036A4B2B0D23FDC141F.description: Interpret the quotient and remainder when solving a contextual problem.

027C737D6133437380247205DC05F224.description:
Estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step contextual problems involving
division with whole numbers.

69072757549F4E1F865C370EAC71F34B.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., rounding, compatible numbers, place value) and algorithms, including
the standard algorithm, to estimate and determine the quotient of two whole numbers, given a
one-digit divisor and a two- or three-digit dividend, with and without remainders.*

48F0A718544047C5B97FAB43F8CD75C5.description:
Estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and multistep contextual
problems that involve multiplication with whole numbers.

1A2C6CDB200D48DDB39318A34ECB6EEE.description: a two-digit factor and a two-digit factor.*

12FAEB9007FA4E28A7EC6633CF775E32.description: a three-digit factor and a one-digit factor;* or

41A2040A41654ED891FAA9641CE58502.description: a two-digit factor and a one-digit factor;*

EAE2F33AE6564C83A9EC8FBEF43EA994.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., rounding, place value, properties of multiplication and/or addition) and
algorithms, including the standard algorithm, to estimate and determine the product of two
whole numbers when given:

928AD2643F164EC59B1ACCAF0CA7B3AD.description: Determine common factors and the greatest common factor of no more than three numbers.

96AE5D9D36544E26928CB2E67B44A6AB.description:
Determine all factor pairs for a whole number 1 to 100, using concrete, pictorial, and
numerical representations.

AAAE461814A4409BB48275B56CFDB9F6.description:
Identify and use the appropriate symbol to distinguish between expressions that are equal and
expressions that are not equal, using addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division (e.g., 4
× 12 = 8 × 6 and 64 ÷ 8 ≠ 8 × 8).

6E1A94B24DDA4AA7A904E8E4E87C8CDF.description:
Create an equation using addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division to represent the
relationship between equivalent mathematical expressions (e.g., 4 × 3 = 2 × 6; 10 + 8 = 36 ÷
2; 12 × 4 = 60 − 12).

D6B124D664E84037925D71A1BC87216C.description:
Recall with automaticity the multiplication facts through 12 × 12 and the corresponding
division facts.*

0B7351FEB6704654B5D89294F304247B.description:
Determine and justify whether an estimate or an exact answer is appropriate when solving
contextual problems involving multiplication and division of whole numbers. Refine
estimates by adjusting the final amount, using terms such as closer to, between, and a little
more than.

C6CC0B6D80D5404DADC176098DEFADE1.description:
The student will estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and
multistep problems, including those in context, using multiplication with whole
numbers, and single-step problems, including those in context, using division with
whole numbers; and recall with automaticity the multiplication facts through 12 × 12
and the corresponding division facts.

3D863E9FCFC74F9596855F860AA73AD4.description:
Estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and multistep contextual
problems involving addition and subtraction with whole numbers where addends and
minuends do not exceed 1,000,000.

2861E28023E8465B8C00ADB24BE0A999.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., place value, properties of addition, other number relationships) and
algorithms, including the standard algorithm, to determine the sum or difference of two whole
numbers, where addends and minuends do not exceed 10,000.*

9B52873B48B244A49C62828C690E9A1D.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., rounding to the nearest 100 or 1,000, using compatible numbers, other
number relationships) to estimate a solution for single-step or multistep addition or
subtraction problems with whole numbers, where addends or minuends do not exceed
10,000.*

5EAD79751F01468DAA56144A62C66347.description:
Determine and justify whether an estimate or an exact answer is appropriate when solving
contextual problems involving addition and subtraction with whole numbers. Refine estimates
by adjusting the final amount, using terms such as closer to, between, and a little more than.

2608926B60E648C88FD88B797E89112D.description:
The student will estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and
multistep problems, including those in context, using addition and subtraction with
whole numbers.

E2C818D5DA94489189751DBE94E5DA0A.description:
Write the decimal and fraction equivalent for a given model (e.g., 1
4
= 0.25 or 0.25 = 1
4
; 1.25 =
5
4
or 11
4
; 1.02 = 102
100
or 1 2
100
).*

2C64AFBB6E35434BAD960CDC877613EB.description:
Identify and model equivalent relationships between fractions (proper or improper) and/or
mixed numbers and decimals, using halves, fourths, fifths, tenths, and hundredths.*

6326E2655ADB42E98D7EFFAC1ED8871C.description:
Represent fractions (proper or improper) and/or mixed numbers as decimals through
hundredths, using multiple representations, limited to halves, fourths, fifths, tenths, and
hundredths.*

91BBE31417984EE0B1D4BB0BCAA0067E.description:
The student will reason about the relationship between fractions and decimals (limited
to halves, fourths, fifths, tenths, and hundredths) to identify and represent
equivalencies.

8DC33529EF7C4F65869BEEEB8B53D765.description:
Compare using symbols (<, >, =) and/or words (greater than, less than, equal to) and order
(least to greatest and greatest to least), a set of no more than four decimals expressed through
thousandths, using multiple strategies (e.g., benchmarks, place value, number lines). Justify
comparisons with a model, orally, and in writing.

9374F5BCD40A4FCBA2FB0E479C7D7392.description:
Identify and communicate, both orally and in written form, the place and value of each digit
in a decimal through thousandths (e.g., given 0.385, the 8 is in the hundredths place and has a
value of 0.08).

70041F85A23641998625C23717B004E6.description:
Read and write decimals expressed through thousandths, using concrete, pictorial, and
numerical representations.

D4547BD129E6445D8CD2983B20912AD4.description:
Represent and identify decimals expressed through thousandths, using concrete, pictorial, and
numerical representations.

C861C99BC53C4C309466F90A1364EF33.description:
Investigate and describe the ten-to-one place value relationship for decimals through
thousandths, using concrete models (e.g., place value mats/charts, decimal squares, base 10
blocks).

3DC8DC63966A410292CDDF1C0B11AF6B.description:
The student will use mathematical reasoning and justification to represent, compare,
and order decimals through thousandths, with and without models.

A7B645E5ADCB42E1BA2746389BF5F645.description:
Represent the division of two whole numbers as a fraction given a contextual situation and a
model (e.g., 3
5
means the same as 3 divided by 5 or 3
5
represents the amount of muffin each of
five children will receive when sharing three muffins equally).

BB2295852B3A4BD3A643CB4B27C4A2FF.description:
Compose and decompose fractions (proper and improper) and/or mixed numbers with
denominators of 12 or less, in multiple ways, with and without models.*

5E4D201B2D7A417B944510331BC8320E.description: Represent equivalent fractions with denominators of 12 or less, with and without models.*

F2E0433792584B72A40A8B5764537642.description:
Compare two fractions (proper or improper) and/or mixed numbers using fractions with
denominators of 12 or less, using the symbols >, <, and = (e.g., 2
3
>
1
7
). Justify comparisons
orally, in writing, or with a model.*

9249A03CC85A4A80AC8B0A35B6BB52E7.description:
Use benchmarks (e.g., 0, 1
2
, or 1) to compare and order no more than four fractions (proper or
improper), and/or mixed numbers, with like and unlike denominators of 12 or less. Justify
comparisons orally, in writing, or with a model.*

C43072D5DE8346618A9C5389CEBABC63.description:
Compare and order no more than four fractions (proper or improper), and/or mixed numbers,
with like numerators and unlike denominators by comparing the size of the parts using
fractions with denominators of 12 or less (e.g., 3
8
<
3
5
). Justify comparisons orally, in writing,
or with a model.*

A08B90B9AD584B88A915EB9A7BBF4554.description:
Compare and order no more than four fractions (proper or improper), and/or mixed numbers,
with like denominators by comparing the number of parts (numerators) using fractions with
denominators of 12 or less (e.g., 1
5
<
3
5
). Justify comparisons orally, in writing, or with a
model.*

8B2CDC248B904D9E81C21751C739727E.description:
The student will use mathematical reasoning and justification to represent, compare,
and order fractions (proper, improper, and mixed numbers with denominators 12 or
less), with and without models.

4CED492BAA2C45738AE0395FAFF7DE2A.description:
Order up to four whole numbers up to seven digits each, from least to greatest or greatest to
least.

6106B0C7BE524B0B97D53C01ADB33CA2.description:
Compare two whole numbers up to seven digits each, using words (greater than, less than,
equal to, not equal to) and/or using symbols (>, <, =, ≠).

3A35046A4A3040C2946B620E8D315AAB.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the base 10 system to compare and
order whole numbers up to seven digits.

EE11EB8EE9AF4D60AC69868004B4AAB9.description:
Apply patterns within the base 10 system to determine and communicate, orally and in written
form, the place and value of each digit in a nine-digit whole number (e.g., in 568,165,724, the
8 represents 8 millions and its value is 8,000,000).

CE4F0FFDA4874D6E909646FBEF73400C.description:
Write nine-digit whole numbers in standard form when the numbers are presented orally or in
written form.

516126B583E74865A6C48EADAFA930FE.description:
Read nine-digit whole numbers, presented in standard form, and represent the same number in
written form.

0775A99AF4E84C2C937745DC59DCFF05.description:
The student will use place value understanding to read, write, and identify the place
and value of each digit in a nine-digit whole number.
